awd_titl_txt: Large Scale Networking (LSN) Workshop on Operationalizing SDN
awd_abstract_narration:
The National Science Foundation, in cooperation with the Large Scale Networks (LSN) Interagency Working Group, has hosted a series of technical workshops over the past 4 years focused on advancing our understanding of the use of Software Defined Networking (SDN) in operational networks. These workshops have convened the academic networking research community, network operators, telecom equipment vendors, and government technologists and regulators in order to share their experience in deploying SDN-capable equipment in various settings.  This proposal seeks participant travel and meeting logistics support for a 2 1/2-day workshop to be held in Washington, DC, on September 18-20, 2017. Approximately 80 participants will represent stakeholders including academia, industry, open-source communities, and government agencies. The workshop will build on the discussions held at the previous two workshops, and facilitate a dialogue to identify research opportunities and achievable milestones for the community to advance the state of operational SDN networks. SDN is critical technology for US IT to retain a competitive advantage in telecommunications and cloud computing.

The proposed workshop provides a timely intellectual exchange among researchers, developers, and operators of SDN technologies. The workshop is expected to: 1) provide an up-to-date understanding of the status and trajectory of SDN development, 2) provide an assessment of the operational goals and gaps of SDN, 3) facilitate discussions of new directions and collaboration opportunities for SDN research and development, 4) provide actionable information for graduate student education and research.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:

The project was launched in 2017 to host the LSN Operationalizing SDN workshop in collaboration with the Large Scale Networking Interagency Working Group on September 18-20, 2017. The workshop was to identify the current state and forward pathways for the realization of an open, innovative, multi-domain and inter-operable SDN as an operational infrastructure during a time of significant academic, industry, and government research and development in the technology space. The workshop brought together 57 attendees amongst university researchers, campus network operators, national and regional research and education (R&E) network operators, local and global commercial network providers, SDN vendors and open source developers, and federal research and mission agencies. Officially published by LSN in 2018, the workshop report not only documented a timely dialogue and historical reflection amongst stakeholder communities for SDN, but it also fostered a myriad of collaborative efforts for SDN, among which is a collaborative effort that will eventually lead to the envisioning, design, and construction of the NSF FABRIC future Internet testbed.

The grant was approved with multiple no-cost extensions in subsequent years till its conclusion in September 2023. Through the five years, the grant team has leveraged its remaining budget to support four more academic workshops on topics centered in advanced networking research. In 2018, the project provided travel grant support for the ONAP Academic Summit (New York City, October 2018) hosted by Dr. Vijay Gopalakrishnan of AT&T. Enduring the COVID-19 pandemic challenges, in 2020 the team hosted the LSN Huge Data Workshop online virtually to discuss challenges and requirements of the emerging “huge-data” sciences and engineering research needs and explore new paradigms to address the problems associated with processing, storing, and transferring huge data. In 2021 the team hosted the Data for AI in Networking Systems Workshop also online virtually to explore the fundamental needs that underpin the uses of AI for networking. In 2022 the team provided travel grant support as co-host for the NSF Midscale Experimental Research Infrastructure Forum (MERIF) Workshop that stimulates innovative research experiments across multiple NSF midscale networking, computing, and edge computing testbeds.

Broader Impact:

Upon conclusion, this workshop grant has supported over all more than 100 researchers in five networking research workshops between 2017 and 2023. In addition to faculty researchers, graduate and undergraduate students have participated in the planning of and participation in the events. Workshop reports, whitepapers, and presentation slide decks published from these workshops have been made available online as open resources for research and education.
